node.text:
Starting a weed business isn't easy. It can take $1 million in startup capital to even get a license. And to keep a cannabis business going? That means jumping through complicated regulation hoops. If they can play the game right, cannabis entrepreneurs could be set up for success in an exploding marijuana industry. But with weed still federally illegal, companies could face fines or jail time if they don't follow the rules. We visited three companies in Colorado and Oregon to see how they're dealing with the ever-changing regulations. Could things get easier if weed becomes federally legal?

Featuring @magichourcannabis.

#Marijuana #THC #Cannabis #Business #WeedBusiness

node.title: Why starting a marijuana business is so hard | Big Business

node.text:
We visited India’s perfume capital, Kannauj to see how craftsmen make "attar," or natural perfumes using a centuries-old steam distillation method.

#Perfume #India #StillStanding

node.title: How India's Perfumers Recreate The Smell Of Rain On Earth

node.text:
One of the biggest cargo planes in the world, the C-17 Globemaster III has a payload capacity of 172,000 pounds. The massive plane is used in a variety of missions, including evacuation efforts and troop transport in Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of Kabul in August 2021. This aircraft requires only three crew members to fly: a pilot, a copilot, and a loadmaster. Insider spent three days at Travis Air Force Base, where we observed the training required to fly these giant $340 million feats of engineering. That training included mastering the flight simulator, planning the proper execution of a mission, and then putting that mission into action with an instructor pilot and performing it in the sky.

#bootcamp #airforce #planes #military #pilot

node.title: What it takes to fly the $340 million C-17 Globemaster III | Boot Camp

node.text: Sam Bernstein and April Koh press pause on their busy days as entrepreneurs to reflect on the companies they each founded at a young age. For Bernstein, that was Table22, which helps restaurants create new revenue streams through subscription kits. For Koh, that was Spring Health, which connects employers to mental wellness resources for workers. Their conversation over coffee, thanks to Philips Espresso 3200 LatteGo, reveals a new style of leadership that prioritizes openness and vulnerability and underscores the need to step away and recharge.

node.title: Two young entrepreneurs reflect on the strength that comes from self-care

node.text:
Polaroid was a photographic giant, at one point controlling two-thirds of the instant camera market in the US. As the digital revolution took over, Polaroid was left exposed, and forced to shut down production in 2008. But the company has found new life thanks to the Impossible Project, by bringing Polaroid’s technology into the digital world.

#Polaroid #Photography #Fujifilm #Kodak #Cameras #Photographer

node.title: The rise and fall of Polaroid | Rise And Fall

node.text:
Durian’s smell is famously divisive. But in Asia and the Pacific Islands, durian is known as the “King of Fruit.” Nonthaburi, Thailand, is known for cultivating some of the most sought-after durian varieties: Kan Yao and Mon Thong. In 2019, one Nonthaburi, or Nont, durian sold at auction for $48,000. So, what makes this pungent, spiky fruit so expensive?

#durian #soexpensive #fruit #nonthaburi #thailand #expensive

node.title: Why Nonthaburi durians are so expensive | So Expensive

node.text:
A lavender farm in West Virginia is restoring land destroyed by coal mining and providing jobs in a state struggling as the fossil fuel energy is on its way out. There are over 6 million acres of abandoned coal mines across the US, and more could go to waste if coal companies don’t restore their land.

#WestVirginia #Lavender #CoalMining #RestoringLand #FossilFuel #Coal #Farming #Environment

node.title: Can lavender save land ruined by coal mining? | World Wide Waste

node.text:
From finishing each piece with a glossy shine to cutting down blocks of wood by hand — it takes over 200 artisans to craft just one Steinway grand piano. Steinway is one of the most famous piano brands in the world, and depending on the model, it can be one of the priciest. A Steinway Model D ebony concert piano will cost you $187,000. Famous pianists and music icons like Billy Joel and Lang Lang play on Steinway pianos. But with several other high-end piano brands on the market, why are musicians so drawn to Steinway? And why are these pianos so expensive?

#Steinway #SteinwayandSons #Piano #Music #MusicalInstrument #SteinwayPiano #Musicians

node.title: Why Steinway grand pianos are so expensive | So Expensive

node.text:
Pottery is a traditional industry in Gaza, supported by families like Sabri Atallah's. But decades of armed conflict and political strife have put these artisans' livelihoods at risk. We visited Sabri Atallah & Sons Pottery Factory before, during, and after the May 2021 attacks to see how he is keeping the craft alive.

Sabri only sells his pottery locally and does not have a website.

#Gaza #Israel #Palestine #Pottery #PotteryShop #MakingPottery #Familyrun #PotteryFactory

node.title: How This Pottery Shop Survived Six Decades Of War And Conflict In Gaza

node.text:
Powerful greenhouse gases lurk inside most refrigerators. One recycling company in Guatemala City is working to keep them out of the atmosphere. Its work is partially funded by carbon offset credits, which experts say can help fight the climate crisis but require close scrutiny.

#Guatemala #GreenhouseGases #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #recycle #RecycleFridge #Environment

node.title: Why refrigerators are so hard to recycle | World Wide Waste

node.text:
Before they can begin their training to become Air Assault-qualified, all students at the Sabalauski Air Assault School must survive "day zero," a physically and mentally grueling test that marks the beginning of what's known as the Army's "10 toughest days." Beginning before sunrise, day zero consists of a detailed inspection of the students' gear, a 2-mile run and culminates with an intimidating obstacle course featuring two major events that all students must conquer — otherwise they are dropped from training before phase one begins. On a scorching day in June where the heat index rose to over 100 degrees, Insider followed two students to find out if they have what it takes to survive day zero and move on to day one of Air Assault School.

Located inside the Fort Campbell Army installation on the Tennessee-Kentucky border, the Air Assault School is where students train to insert themselves and equipment into combat using helicopters. 

#AirAssault #AirAssaultSchool #FortCampbell #Army #BootCamp

node.title: What it takes to survive the Army's 'day zero' at Air Assault School

node.text:

node.accessibility_caption: Photo showing headline, "A majority of US companies say they're planning to require employees to get vaccinated by the end of the year:  according to a survey first reported by Reuters"

node.text:
Half of US companies are planning to require workers get a COVID-19 vaccine by the end of 2021. Willis Towers Watson polled 961 US companies that employ a total of around 9.7 million people. Apple, Goldman Sachs, and Uber are requiring some or all employees get a COVID-19 vaccine.

Click the link in our bio to read the findings.

(Credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters)
#CovidVaccinations #CovidI9 #DeltaVariant

#steinway #steinwaypianos #pianos #howitsmade #grandpianos

node.accessibility_caption: Photo showing San Jose with headline, "The US cities where retiring comfortably will cost you the most"

node.text:
If you want to retire comfortably, you could need $2 million or more in these US 14 cities. GOBankingRates data shows the cost of a comfortable life in cities across the US. The most expensive cities include San Francisco, San Jose, and Honolulu.

Click the link in our bio to see the full list.

(Credit: Sean Duan/Getty, Shutterstock, Matteo Colombo/Getty Images, DenisTangneyJr/Getty Images, Alexander Spatari/Getty Images, Mario Tama/Getty Images, Kat Wade/Getty Images, Robert Galbraith/Reuters)
#RetirementPlan #RetiredLife #ExpensiveCities

node.accessibility_caption: Photo showing San Jose with headline, "The US cities where retiring comfortably will cost you the most"
Photo showing San Diego with text, "San Diego is the cheapest of the California cities on this list, but it could still cost upwards of $130,000 per year. "
Photo showing Seattle with text, "Seattle offers retirees an abundance of nature, but also high costs of living. "
Photo showing Oakland with text, "Retiring in Oakland, California, could require about $3.6 million in savings."
Photo showing New York City with text, "Living and retiring comfortably in New York City could cost well over $140,000 per year."
Photo showing Los Angeles with text, "In Los Angeles, living comfortably will cost about $150,000 per year. "
Photo showing Hawaii with text, "Honolulu is picturesque, but it's also the third most expensive city on this list."
Photo showing San Francisco with text, "San Francisco is the most expensive city on this list: It would take a nest egg of $5.7 million to retire comfortably here."

Photo by Business Insider on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER The latest numbers from data firm Reonomy suggest remote work is significantly slowing down office investment'.

node.text:
Data shows that office investment is down 30% through July compared with the same period in 2019. Some are taking this as a sign that office demand will permanently drop thanks to an era of remote work. 

Investors who buy and sell office space are closely tracking the office market for signs of a return to normal or their worst-case scenario: a long-term decline in the need for physical workplaces.

This data gives a breakdown of the cities which have been impacted the most by the lack of need for a physical office.

To read more and see which other cities feature on the list, click the link in our bio.

Story by Alex Nicoll.

[Credit: John Lamb/The Image Bank/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER The latest numbers from data firm Reonomy suggest remote work is significantly slowing down office investment'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER Percentages show how much lower the office-investment sales numbers for each city were in the first seven months of this year versus the first seven months of 2019 San Francisco: 49.05% Charlotte, North Carolina: 52.44% Orlando, Florida: 56.72% Philadelphia: 65.06% Raleigh, North Carolina: 64.92% St. Louis: 66.67% Minneapolis and St. Paul: 72.92%'.
Photo showing a shot from the show "The Office" with headline, "The most successful teams swear and gossip. Managers, take note."

node.text:
A new survey finds that high-performing team members act more like friends than coworkers. Team members are more likely to joke, use GIFs and emojis, and discuss nonwork matters. The findings have implications for managers devising best practices for the post-pandemic workplace.

Click the link in our bio to read the findings.

(Credit: Chris Haston/NBCU Photo Bank/NBCUniversal via Getty Images via Getty Image)
#TeamBuilding #WorkFromHome #WorkLife

node.accessibility_caption: Photo showing a shot from the show "The Office" with headline, "The most successful teams swear and gossip. Managers, take note."

Photo showing text, "Survey: The survey, from Ignite80,  a learning and development company, finds that high-performing teams are more likely to joke around, use GIFs and emojis in digital messaging, tease their teammates, and swear around coworkers than low-performing teams. 

Team members are also more likely to discuss nonwork matters. They, for instance, talk about books, gossip, and go out for coffee or drinks. In short, they act more like friends than coworkers."

Photo showing text, "Lessons for managers: Members of high-performing teams are more likely to express and receive appreciation for their contributions than lower-performing teams. The findings also underscore distinct differences between high- and lower-performing teams in terms of communication cadence, frequency, 
and substance. 

Managers must strike the right balance between cultivating close relationships and also making sure people feel they can successfully turn off. One way to do this is by creating norms and expectations for intra-team communication."

A graphic shows a headshot of Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes and a background image of Theranos promotion highlighting the small vials of blood they claimed they used for blood tests. The graphic reads: Embattled Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes is about to go on trial for fraud. Here's everything you need to know.

node.text:
Blood-testing startup Theranos and its founder, Elizabeth Holmes, were once the subjects of spectacular praise, hailed for their promise to revolutionize diagnostic testing in healthcare. Now, Holmes is a defendant in a federal fraud trial that begins Tuesday.

Holmes and former COO Ramesh Balwani are accused of defrauding investors, doctors, and patients. If she's convicted, Holmes faces up to 20 years in prison, $2.75 million in fines, and restitution.

Click the link in our bio to read the full story by Sarah Jackson.

(Credit: Amina Kilpatrick/Insider, Reuters, Getty Images, Theranos)

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows a headshot of Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes and a background image of Theranos promotion highlighting the small vials of blood they claimed they used for blood tests. The graphic reads: Embattled Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes is about to go on trial for fraud. Here's everything you need to know.

A graphic shows an headshot of Elizabeth Holmes wearing a black turtleneck. It reads: Who is Elizabeth Holmes?  Holmes studied chemical engineering at Stanford before dropping out in 2003 to work on Theranos when she was 19. In 2014, she was dubbed the world's youngest self-made female billionaire, boasting an estimated net worth of $4.5 billion. Taking after Steve Jobs, one of her heroes, Holmes often donned black turtlenecks and never took vacations.

A graphic shows a vial of blood smaller than the stand size most medical places use to draw blood. It reads: What was Theranos? Theranos was a blood-testing startup that developed a test for a variety of health conditions with blood from a single finger prick, unlike traditional blood tests, which often require multiple vials of blood.Theranos' tests also promised to be cheaper, faster, and more accurate than traditional blood tests. At its peak, Theranos was valued at $9 billion.

A graphic shows a headshot image of Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani wearing a suit and tie. It reads: Who is Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani? Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani was president and COO of Theranos.
Balwani and Holmes, who is roughly 20 years his junior, met in Beijing through Stanford's summer Mandarin program in the summer before Holmes went to college. Around the time Holmes dropped out of Stanford, they became romantically involved. They broke up in 2016 and Balwani left the company that year.

A text-only graphic reads: What caused Theranos' downfall? Aug 2015: FDA investigators deamdned to inspect Theranos' facilies, government regulators found major inacuracies in Theranos' tests. Oct 2015: Only 15 of the 240 test Theranos offere were performed by the company's Edison machines according to the Wall Street Journa. July 2016: SEC began investigation Theranos. Lab operations and wellness centers close months later. June 2018: Holmes stepped down as CEO on the same day the Department of Jutice charged her with wire fraud and conspiracy.

A text-only graphic reads: 
What are the charges and possible punishments? Holmes and Balwani are each charged with two counts of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and nine counts of wire fraud. If they're convicted, for each count, they'll face up to 20 years in prison, a fine of $250,000, and restitution to victims.  The US Department of Justice alleges that Holmes and Balwani took part in schemes to defraud investors, doctors, and patients by making deceptive claims about Theranos, its financial outlook, and its technology.

A text-only graphic reads: How have Holmes and Balwani responded to the allegations? Holmes and Balwani have both pleaded not guilty to the charges. After John Carreyrou published his bombshell story in the Wall Street Journal, Holmes responded by saying, "This is what happens when you work to change things. First they think you're crazy, then they fight you, and then all of a sudden you change the world."

A text only graphic reads: Who were Theranos' investors and board members? Some of the company's biggest investors included former US Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos, and members of the Walton family, who are heirs to the Walmart empire.

A text-only graphic reads: What's next? Jury selection begins Tuesday, and opening statements are slated for September 8. The trial had previously been delayed due to COVID-19. 

In March, Holmes requested and received a delay because she was pregnant. 

A separate trial for Balwani will start in January.

node.text:
Starting a weed business isn't easy. It can take $1 million in startup capital to even get a license. And to keep a cannabis business going? That means jumping through complicated regulation hoops. If they can play the game right, cannabis entrepreneurs could be set up for success in an exploding marijuana industry. But with weed still federally illegal, companies could face fines or jail time if they don't follow the rules. We visited three companies in Colorado and Oregon to see how they're dealing with the ever-changing regulations. Could things get easier if weed becomes federally legal?

Featuring @magichourcannabis.

#Marijuana #THC #Cannabis #Business #WeedBusiness

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows the Golden Gate Bridge in San Fransico. It reads: These are the 28 US cities where managers are the most open to letting their employees keep working remotely after the pandemic

node.text:
Managers in these cities are the most open to long-term remote work post-COVID.

A recent survey from HR consulting firm Robert Half pinned down the 28 US cities where the biggest percentage of managers say they'll let employees work remotely part- or full-time once COVID-19 restrictions are gone. 

In Boston, which led the pack, 45% of managers will let remote work continue once restrictions lift. Click the link in our bio to see the other 21 cities with managers most open to remote work.

Story by Sarah Jackson.

(Credit: Amina Kilpatrick/ Insider, Shutterstock, Getty Images, AP Photo)

A graphic shows freight ships sitting off the coast of California in January with arrows pointing to the ships. The text reads: A record-breaking 44 container ships are stuck off the coast of California

node.text:
Forty-four freight ships are stuck awaiting entry into California's two largest ports, breaking the previous record since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic of 40 ships, the Marine Exchange of Southern California reported on Saturday.

The ports account for about one-third of US imports, serving as a main source of trade with China.
The queue is a result of the labor shortage, COVID-19-related disruptions, and holiday-buying surges. 

Port of Los Angeles data indicated that the ships' average wait time had increased to 7.6 days. 

(Credit: Getty Images)

node.text: How to open a brokerage account and how to buy a stock. We’ll also offer tips for building your portfolio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Under $200K 100% Share of new homes sold by price Over $400K $200K $400K 80% 60% 40% 20% 0% 2002 2008 2014 Source: US Census Bureau via FRED 2020 INSIDER'.

node.text:
In 2002, more than half of new homes sold for under $200,000. In July 2021, less than 2% did, while nearly half sold for over $400,000.

This chart chart shows the death of the American starter home over the last 2 decades. Homeownership has become increasingly unaffordable for the American middle class, and it's getting worse.

(Credit: Taylor Tyson/@bi_graphics)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on August 30, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Premium DENVER $176K SF $207K MIAMI $167K INSIDER There's a battle brewing over salaries for remote workers and it could change the way everyone gets paid'.

node.text:
It's always been the ultimate dream of remote work: living in luxury, somewhere cheap, on a big-city salary. 

But some tech giants have decided to play hardball with employees who want to relocate for good. Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter, Dropbox, and a host of other Silicon Valley mainstays have told their employees that if they move away from pricey cities, they should expect to get their salaries cut — in some cases by as much as 25%.

Click the link in our bio to subscribe to Insider and read the full story on the battle over salaries for remote workers.

Story by Aki Ito.

(Credit: Samantha Lee/Insider)

#remotework #remotejobs #salary #careers #jobs
